Comment: My understanding is that decision is in response to the ruling from Xinis which was that Trump had no legal grounds to deport Garcia without "due process" and that the AEA could not be used at all. In typical recent SCOTUS fashion the court issued that vague 9-0 ruling that has become open to interpretation. Trump, on one hand, took that ruling to mean he could deport any who had gang or criminal affiliations without "due process" while the left thinks that all have the ability to go through the entire court system before a decision is rendered on their deportability.  Generally speaking, as you know, any who come here illegally are entitled to have a hearing before an immigration court to determine their deportation status. The biggest issue with that is the sheer number of petitioners. It should be that the finding of the immigration court is binding and the process ends there. Trump is trying to speed up the process of deporting suspected, and sometimes known, alien criminals and gang members who I believe don't get the benefit of the doubt. They didn't come through a port of entry and therefore many, including me, believe they've forfeited any perceived rights they may have had under our law. Even Biden and Obama practiced catch and release of those who come over the border illegally without giving them any "due process".  The leftists are trying to gum up our legal system with this hoping for a favorable ruling from SCOTUS that they can use as precedent to apply to *all* immigration cases (see the Garcia case). Trump, in part through the AEA is arguing the exact opposite, that the executive has the right and the duty to expel those who fall under the gang and criminal category.  Until we get something definitive from SCOTUS that can be used as precedent for all immigration cases we'll continue down the path we're on now. But whether they're overwhelmed as you suggest or simply don't take a stand at all this legal jockeying looks to continue. Hopefully SCOTUS will decide next month that the decisions handed down by district court judges cannot be applied nationally as they have been. That would be a positive first step to clear all this up. Until then? Who the hell knows.
